Do Lambda expressions improve efficiency at any rate?
Is there any difference between using a Lambda expression and the generic method of doing the same thing? (aside from saving like 5 lines for the syntax)

Also, I never knew Java had labels :o
[/quote]any overhead of using a lambda will be minuscule and irrelevant, so it is basically a syntactical convenience[/quote]

Thanks ^^

item.title: Java 8
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“tyb97, post:28, topic:468908”]I don’t even understand how lambda expressions work… I know it’s something to do with -> but, what it does, I have no idea.[/quote]say we have an array of some sort

and we want to iterate it and print out the shit within. traditionally and imperatively you’d do this

for (int i = 0; i < array.length; i++) { System.out.println(array[i]); }

however, that’s quite verbose and we’re explicitly stating the order in which the array is being iterated through with an ugly temporary variable used simply as a record for us to know which array element is being accessed (i)

enter: a foreach function, which is a function that takes a function and applies it to all elements of the list. think of it something like (in the case of an int[]) the following pseudocode

int[] foreach(function func, int[] array) { for (int i = 0; i < array.length; i++) func(array[i]); }

now the function bit is a bit of wizardry, because we’ve now encapsulated the explicit looping with its own function and now we can reuse the foreach function without having to write a new loop with a new temporary i variable

we can now write

foreach(System.out::println, array); to print out all the elements of our array (the :: bit is just some syntax ignore it)

anonymous functions/lambdas become useful here because what if we want to print out our array with an exclamation mark at the end of every element instead? well, without lambdas we’d write up a new function

void printNumber(int n) { System.out.println(n + "!"); }

and make the foreach call as

however, that requires explicitly naming a function, which can be inconvenient and irritating if the function is only used once. basically it’s a waste. so enter functions without a name that can be used once and never again, these are basically lambdas. with our new found syntax, we can basically do

and now we’re not wasting the name & space on a function that we only use once, as we’ve now made it anonymous.

Read full topic

Looks like Brian Goetz and the JDK just made a major syntax decision for closures (lambdas) in Java 8:  This just in: the EG has (mostly) made a decision...

somewhat relevant!

item.title: Java 8
item.dc:creator: @Uncalled Uncalled
item.description:
@Uncalled wrote:

[quote=“sppt, post:26, topic:468908”][quote author=Uncalled link=topic=585922.msg4161509#msg4161509 date=1353170895]

Does anyone besides me dislike lambda expressions?
[/quote]No, I think they look fugly written out.

You should see one of the early versions of lambda support, I tried it out back then, and to use em, you had to do something like this:

[code=java]public class Main {

interface TEST { int foo(int i); }
interface TEST2 { int foo(); }
interface TEST3 { void test(String s);}

public Main() {
    TEST i = (int x) -> x+1;
    TEST2 i2 = () -> 42;
    TEST3 s = (String s2) -> {System.out.println(s2);};
    System.out.println((i.foo(3)));
    System.out.println(i2.foo());
    s.test("Hello, World!");
}
public static void main(String[] args) {
    Main m = new Main();
}

}[/code]

First you defined an interface which the lambda will use, then create a new object of said interface, and invoke the method specified in the interface.
That was flippin atrocious.[/quote]That looks flippin atrocious. That would suck!

Read full topic

item.title: Java 8
item.dc:creator: @sppt sppt
item.description:
@sppt wrote:

[quote=“Uncalled, post:21, topic:468908”][quote author=Rodgerwilco link=topic=585922.msg4161500#msg4161500 date=1353170241]
Does anyone besides me dislike lambda expressions?
[/quote]No, I think they look fugly written out.[/quote]
You should see one of the early versions of lambda support, I tried it out back then, and to use em, you had to do something like this:

[code=java]public class Main {

interface TEST { int foo(int i); }
interface TEST2 { int foo(); }
interface TEST3 { void test(String s);}

public Main() {
    TEST i = (int x) -> x+1;
    TEST2 i2 = () -> 42;
    TEST3 s = (String s2) -> {System.out.println(s2);};
    System.out.println((i.foo(3)));
    System.out.println(i2.foo());
    s.test("Hello, World!");
}
public static void main(String[] args) {
    Main m = new Main();
}

}[/code]

First you defined an interface which the lambda will use, then create a new object of said interface, and invoke the method specified in the interface.
That was flippin atrocious.

Read full topic

item.title: Java 8
item.dc:creator: @Supah_Flyizzle Supah Flyizzle
item.description:
@Supah_Flyizzle wrote:

[quote=“tyb97, post:10, topic:468908”][quote author=vortex link=topic=585922.msg4160940#msg4160940 date=1353102726]

I think it would be cool to see the “goto” keyword get implemented
[/quote]You mean the same “goto” that has been there since like 1.0 or something?

It’s not useable… It’s only a restricted keyword…[/quote]

because goto statements are shit. they mess with control flow and make your application a nightmare. i can’t think of one occasion where i was like “hey, you know what i really need, but don’t have? the ability to jump around my method and have confusing code for no real purpose!” that being said, you can and should accomplish what you would with goto statements using the available constructs of the language.

c# has lambdas. [size=6pt]not to mention better generics, a more consistent api, better documentation, and a bunch of ACTUALLY useful features. [/size]

the only reason i’m saying this is because you should actually go TRY it with a solid, stable implementation (not really subject to change) of most of these features (parallel array sorting too!). i don’t even know if they even added the lambda stuff yet and any other changes are pretty far down the line. jdk 8 hasn’t even reached feature complete, let alone a potentially stable release. go try it, you might find it more useful than you think. also you’ll be subject to something that isn’t java which is always good for… culture and perspective.

Read full topic

They are awesome useful. Plus, they changed the syntax since Java 7. Iirc, they were going to use hashes to designate the start of an anonymous function, but then they changed it. I like this one much better.[/quote]

item.title: Java 8
item.dc:creator: @sppt sppt
item.description:
@sppt wrote:

[quote=“sinisoul, post:5, topic:468908”][quote author=sppt link=topic=585922.msg4160895#msg4160895 date=1353099050]
I’d love for them to implement properties, cuz I hate making getters and setters, and they always teach you you can’t use public variables for anything at all, which sucks ass.
[/quote]

I agree, this would be nice. I’ve seen some cool things come from java 8 although I can’t remember anything specifically I like except for the new concurrency package.[/quote]
I’d love to have extensions methods as well, and while we’re at it, let’s just import all features c# has that java doesn’t!

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:6, topic:468908”][quote author=sppt link=topic=585922.msg4160895#msg4160895 date=1353099050]
I’d love for them to implement properties, cuz I hate making getters and setters, and they always teach you you can’t use public variables for anything at all, which sucks ass.
[/quote]
Eclipse and Netbeans can generate this for you. But why shouldn’t you use public variables? (Apart from the obvious).[/quote]
Those are both shit, use Intellij IDEA, the best IDE there is for java.
And yes, IDEs can do that, but it’s just ugly as fucking shit.

Also, every lecturer is like “Oh Em Gee, Public variables are always bad in any context!!1!”, it pisses me off.
Especially without properties, it’s such a pain in the ass.

Read full topic

item.title: Java 8
item.dc:creator: @tyb97 tyb97
item.description:
@tyb97 wrote:

[quote=“imthenull, post:14, topic:468908”]That’s incorrect Bowser. break label; is only used to break out of the current label.

start: for (int i = 0; i < 10; ++i) { if (i == 5) // break from this label, stopping the current loop break start; System.out.println(i); } System.out.println("Hello world.");[/quote]
Yep… Anyone else wish to try to disprove me?

Read full topic

item.title: Java 8
item.dc:creator: @imthenull imthenull
item.description:
@imthenull wrote:

That’s incorrect Bowser. break label; is only used to break out of the current label.

start: for (int i = 0; i < 10; ++i) { if (i == 5) // break from this label, stopping the current loop break start; System.out.println(i); } System.out.println("Hello world.");

Read full topic
